STUDENT LIFE IN EDINBURGH.

10

s,
.0
r.

d.

3t.

Life in a Scotch college is well and economically ordered upon the basis of student selfgovernment. There is no needless interference
on the part of the authorities. There is no
watching or supervising, no gating," or shutting in of students at an early evening hour, as
in an English college. In Edinburgh a
student-lodger, as in America, has his own
pass-key and comes or goes when he likes. A
College Hall in Scotland is managed very
much like an American City Club or College
Fraternity House. The Hall chooses its own
officers. A house committee has general
charge of all matters of interior concern. Only
those students are received as members who
are approved or elected. Any obnoxious member may be disciplined or expelled.
The
Charges made for rooms, which are furnished
with all things needful, are according to location. The cost of board is assessed pro rata
upon the members of the common mess, exactly as in old-fashioned student commons, or
dining clubs, at Harvard and Yale.
In the Scotch, as well as in the English colleges, a visitor is impressed with the good administration and efficient household service.
There is a well-developed spirit of social unity
and good fellowship. In these points our
American dormitory system at boys' schools
and men's colleges is, in most cases, weak. The
service and management are usually bad. Our
American colleges for women are far superior
to the old-fashioned dormitories for men. At
Smith and Bryn Mawr, as in English and
Scotch colleges, you will find common diningrooms and common parlors in the buildings
where students lodge. This, of course, promotes sociability, and the common life, which,
in men's colleges, is too often relegated to the

No. 4

fraternity house, the gymnasium, the "cage,"
or the ball field. To this general rule there are
wholesome exceptions a t Lawrenceville,
Worcester Free Academy, Rutger's College,
Trinity College, N. C., and other places.
• The experience of Oxford, Cambridge and
Edinburgh Universities has shown the possibility of good social organization in dormitories and of a real common life in large academic towns, where the individual, unless living in some college, is in danger of isolation
and a more or less hermit mode of existence.
Especially in Edinburgh has the institution of
University Halls, on Castle Hill, socialized and
unified the hitherto separate and scattered elements of the great student body. It is both
feasible and desirable in American college
towns to bring together, in the form of Students' Unions, little bands of congenial spirits,
who can form social clubs, or open fraternities,
to which desirable members may be gradually
elected, upon a broad and liberal plan. The
upper rooms of the club-house, as in our present fraternity houses, should be rented to members. There should be a common room, or
parlor, and a dining-room on the first floor, a
club cuisine in the basement, and bathrooms in
all the upper stories. A club mess can easily be
sustained by residents and boarders under the
direction of a student manager or steward,
who should cater for the club mess and regulate expenses according to the wishes of its patrons. The business affairs of the club, the
election of new members, the collection of
rents, dues, etc., should be in charge of a house
committee. This kind of administration is well
understood in some of our American College
Fraternities, but it needs social extension and
academic popularization.
In the Scotch College Hall at Ramsay Garden I was greatly impressed with the interior
art decorations. As you ascend the winding
stairways, you find the walls beautifully

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

adorned with hundreds of photographs of Old
Edinburgh buildings. Modern improvements
in the "Old Town" on the hill have caused
the removal of many ancient landmarks and
historic monuments, architectural facades and
picturesque courts, or ancient "wyndes,"
which were once the artist's and tourist's delight. You will now find them all preserved in
artistic ways, by drawings and photographs on
the staircases of the College Hall at Ramsay
Garden. In the common room of this hall the
walls are artistically frescoed to represent certain scenes in Celtic mythology. There is an
earnest attempt every year at the Edinburgh
Summer School to revive old Celtic decorative
art, of which a pleasing exhibition is made on
academic premises and in prints and publications.
Edinburgh is a wonderfully beautiful town,
a queenly city, a modern Athens, set upon hills,
with broad thoroughfares, noble monuments
and public buildings, lovely gardens, extensive
parks and drives, magnificent outlooks towards
the mountains and across the Firth of Forth.
But some idea of what the condition of the
town once was can be obtained by glancing at
the squalid "survivals" of filth and misery
in "Cowgate" and other old-time streets and
alleys in which now dwell "the submerged
tenth," apparently sunken below the present
level of the city, whose traffic and modern
promenades are more conspicuously seen
along those gigantic causeways which cross the
old historic ravines or gullies of Edinburgh.
In the newest art gallery of the city you will
find in an upper room a large collection of
sketches and water colors, showing Old Edinburgh in all its picturesque squalor. Almost
every bit of quaint architecture, every nook and
corner of the ancient town, is thus immortalized by the faithful hand of art ; but we must
remember that those old rookeries on High
street and Canongate, while interesting to look
at, were not sanitary places of abode. As Robert Louis Stevenson says : "It is easy to be a
conservator of the discomforts of others. . . .
Assuredly, in driving streets through the black
labyrinth, a few curious old corners have been
swept away, and some associations turned out

of house and home. But what slices of sunlight, what breaths of clean of air, have been
let in I And what a picturesque world remains
untouched I"
Whoever visits Edinburgh will be grateful
to the memory of Robert Louis Stevenson, and
will read and re-read his "Picturesque Notes"
on this fascinating old city. No writer has better caught the spirit of the place or sketched its
salient features with a truer hand. The visitor
will surely encounter this genius loci, Robert
Louis Stevenson, in the National Portrait Gallery of Edinburgh, where a marble bust of the
charming author of "St. Ives" greets you
with an almost life-like welcome. The man
truly lives in literature and in art. The following brief extracts from his "Picturesque Notes"
describe Edinburgh :
"Few places, if any," he says, "offer a more
barbaric display of contrasts to the eye. In the
very midst stands one of the most satisfactory
crags in nature—a bass rock upon dry land,
rooted in a garden, shaken by passing trains,
carrying a crown of battlements and turrets,
and describing its warlike shadow over the
liveliest and brightest thoroughfare of the New
Town. From their smoky beehives, ten stories
high, the unwashed look down upon the open
squares and gardens of the wealthy ; and gay
people sunning themselves along Princes
street, with its mile of commercial palaces beflagged upon some great occasion, see, across a
gardened valley set with statues, where the
washings of the old town flutter in the breeze
at its high windows. And then, upon all sides,
what a clashing of architecture I In this one
valley, where the life of the town goes most
busily forward, there may be seen, shown one
above and behind another by the accidents of
the ground, buildings in almost every style
upon the globe. Egyptian and Greek temples,
Venetian palaces and Gothic spires, are huddled one over another in a most admired disorder; while, above all, the brute mass of the
Castle and the summit of Arthur's Seat look
down upon these imitations with a becoming
dignity, as the works of Nature may look down
upon the monuments of Art."
HERBERT B. ADAMS.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. T11-1011AS.

Dr. James Carey Thomas was born in Baltimore on July II, 1833, and died on November
9, 1897. He graduated from Haverford College in 1852, and from the Medical School of
the University of Maryland in 1854. He was
a trustee of the Johns Hopkins University from
its opening until his death.
His efficient, faithful and devoted work in
many lines is known to all men. He was a
physician in the active practice of that arduous
profession, a minister of the 'Gospel in the Society of Friends, a public-spirited philanthropist, keenly interested in every plan for the improvement of his fellowman ; an officer and a
zealous supporter of the Young Men's Christian Association in this city, and a trustee of
several important educational institutions.
This is not the place to write of these manifold
fields of activity. But it is eminently fitting that
reference should be made in THE NEWS-LETTER to another side of Dr. Thomas' activity to
which he gave much time, thought and love—
his relations to the Johns Hopkins University.
Only the trustees can tell how valuable his
services were in the organization and development of the University in general, and of the
Medical School in particular; but certain of
Dr. Thomas' services were such as could be
seen even by those who came here as students,
and still more clearly by those who remained
as instructors, after the conclusion of their
course of studies for a degree.
First of all, he stood for a broad and courageous Christianity in the University. Other
men might doubt as to the position of Christianity in the mind of an educated man or in the
life of an educational institution ; but we felt
that in him we knew one who never hesitated
in his firm insistence on the greatest freedom
of scientific research and on the certainty and
importance of the Christian religion. None
Should be ignorantly religious; none should
be learned infidels —all should be educated
Christians. With such convictions, he was a
most eager and consistent supporter of everything which tended to make the religious life
more vital to the students.

3

Another service, rendered by Dr. Thomas to
the University, came from his broad culture.
He was the member of the Board of Trustees
with whom (next to President Gilman) the students most frequently came in contact, and in
him we found the true University spirit. He
had none of that narrow specialization into
which professional men are so liable to fall ;
none of that distortion of perspective which
makes the science studied by you so important
and those studied by others so insignificant. In
him we knew a man whose outlook was over a
wide field. He was a truly liberal man. Liberality has been defined as "breadth on high levels," and it seems to me that Dr. Thomas' life
fulfilled that definition. Shallowness was as
foreign to him as narrowness. His breadth
was that of the deep and mighty ocean.
Finally, his life was one of great influence on
Hopkins men because of its kindliness, purity
and lovableness. One could not meet him without a friendly word. To chat with him was to
catch an inspiration to effort, which lingered
long after the conversation was finished. He
was so cheerful, so buoyant and hopeful in his
view of life, so filled with brotherly kindness,
and his face was so turned towards those things
that are pure and lovely, that his presence was
a benediction. Good was it for so many of us
that we knew him,and good was it for the University that his influence was so long manifested and so potent here.
BERNARD C. STEINER.

A meeting of the class of '99 was held on
Wednesday, November 3. The financial situation of the class was discussed and an assessment made. Mr. Dieffenbach addressed the
meeting in behalf of The '98 Hullabaloo. The
class voted an appropriation of $20 to The Hullabaloo. The election of class historian was
postponed until next meeting.

COLLEGE CONGRESS.

The second regular session of the Senate,
held on Wednesday, November 17, was decidedly more interesting and spirited than the
previous meeting. The debaters displayed
greater self-possession, and were, therefore,
more effective. The side which affirmed that
the "silver question" was now a dead issue, represented by Senators Fisher, R. D. Miller and
Fitzgerald, won by an overwhelming majority.
Senators Fisher and Miller were heartily applauded. The open discussion was participated
in by Senators Ballard and Miller. The meeting was honored by the presence of Professor
Adams, who afterwards gave a favorable criticism of the debate. His advice to the speakers
is to write down their address, as an effective
method of impressing it on the memory, but to
use no notes in speaking, as it is most important to be independent in the delivery.
The subject for the next debate is : Shall
the United States intervene in behalf of Cuba?"
Senators Seth, Clark and Pender will take the
affirmative; Senators Ulman, Stearns and
Hammond 'the negative. President Gilman
will probably be present as the guest of the
Senate.
The third regular meeting of the House of
Representatives was held Wednesday, October
10, in the Donovan room, McCoy ,Hall. Dr.
Adams was the guest of the House. The subject debated was: "Resolved, That the result
of the work of the United States Bimetallic
Monetary 'Commission ought definitely to settle the silver question." The affirmative side
was taken by Congressmen Greenbaum, Fosnocht and Frank; the negative side by Congressmen Gaddess, Levering and Kalb. The
question was very ably debated, and the arguments were effective, especially those of Fosnocht, Levering and Frank. The House took
a very active part in the open discussion. Dr.
Adams, at the request of the House, spoke a
few words. He complimented both the debaters and the House on their able discussion of
the question. The subject for debate at the next

meeting of the House will be : "Resolved, That
the United States should intervene in behalf of
Cuba." The affirmative side will be taken by
Congressmen Chambers, Bruce and Ramsay;
the negative side by Congressmen Fisher, Ross
and Guggenheimer. Dr. Vincent will be the
guest of the House.

ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION.

The newly-organized General Athletic Association is taking active steps to better the
condition of athletics at the University. A field
will be secured and the rent guaranteed for five
years. Five thousand dollars are to be raised,
with the assistance of the alumni, which will be
expended in fitting up the grounds. This will
give our teams next spring good grounds for
out-of-door practice, in addition to the facilities
which the cage will afford, and will also enable
them to make some money on the gate receipts
at games. The graduates and alumni members of the governing board of the Association

THE NEWS-LETTER.
were elected at the last meeting. They are:
Dr. Renouf, Allan McLane, Robert Garrett
and W. H. Maddren. The undergraduate
members of the board will be elected by the
various classes.
THE LITERARY PRIZES.

A few days only remain until December I,
when the time appointed for THE NEWS-LETTER literary contest will close. The Thanksgiving holidays have given some relief from
regular work, and afford an opportunity to
those who have found themselves too busy to
compete. Prof. Adams, Prof. Greene and
Mr. Guy Carleton Lee have consented to act
as judges. The offer is open to students in all
departments of the University. The conditions
are broad, and the prizes are as liberal as we
can make them. The copy of THE NEWSLETTER containing the winning compositions
will go to the exchange table of every prominent college paper in the country. It is important that we be well represented. We look to
the students to make the contest a success.

Prof. Brooks will deliver a series of lectures
on "The Principles of Science as Illustrated by
Zoology," beginning on Monday, November
29,at 5 P. M. These lectures will be held in the
lecture room of the Biological Laboratory, and
are not open to the public.
The Philological Association met Friday,
November 19. Principal paper, "The Sources
of Davenart's Albovine" and "Siege of
Rhodes," Mr. Killis Campbell. Minor communication,"The Arrangement of the Fables
of Marie de France," Mr. Murray Brush.
Dr. F. R. Jones, instructor in political economy has accepted the position of instructor in
history and politics at Union College, Schenectady, N. Y. He left Baltimore last week,
and Dr. Hollander has taken the class in political economy in his stead.

5

President Gilman has been appointed by the
Mayor one of five citizens to act with the law
officers of the city in drafting a new charter for
the city of Baltimore.
The current number of the Johns Hopkins
University Circular, contains a sketch of Dr.
Humphrey by J. S. Kingsley and B. W. Barton, and a sketch of Dr. Conant by George
Lefevre.
President Gilman has invited Dr. and Mrs.
Nansen to stay at his house during their sojourn in Baltimore.
rIEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

The first Pithotomy of the present academic
year was given on November 27th, at 9 P. M.,
by the fourth year meds., to the rest of that
class and to the faculty and Hospital staff. The
meeting was at the Phi Kappa Psi house. It
included all that was necessary for the comfort
of those present in the line of smoke and drink.
The literary part of the entertainment consisted of stories and songs by various members
of the staff, besides original topical songs by
Mr. Dawson, of the fourth year. The word
"Pithotomy" was coined by the originators of
the society, and is derived from the Greek
word Pithos—"beer jug."
Messrs. Brown and Oliver of the third-year
class have been made demonstrators in anatomy. Messrs. Flint, McCallum and Lewis of
the second-year class have been made assistants in histology. Miss Sabine, also of the second-year class, is now demonstrator in anatomy.
Miss Sabine is about to publish in the Hopkins Hospital reports an article on "The Seventh Cranial."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. REID'S TRIP.

THE LECTURES ON JAPAN.

Dr. H. F. Reid returned from his summer's
trip on Wednesday November 17. He left
Baltimore on June 12, and spent some weeks
taking measurements on the Forno glacier in
the Engadin, together with Professor Ames.
From Switzerland he went to Russia, to take
part in an extensive journey of geologists
across the Ural as far as the Western terminus
of the Great Siberian road. After this he
met Dr. Clark at St. Petersburg, took part in
the Congress, and then joined in a special trip
to Mt. Elbrux in the Caucasus.
In the first days of October an excursion was
made to Mt. Ararat. Mr. E. Stoeber, who ascended the greater Ararat, together with Dr.
Ebeling, of Berlin, and Dr. Oswald, of Bale,
separated from his companions. They gained
the summit, were forced to spend the night at
an altitude of 16,000 feet, suffering much from
cold, and returned to the Cossack camp next
day. There they learned that Stoeber had not
returned. An instant search after the lost man
was rendered fruitless through a violent snowstorm and through the men's inability to speak
Russian with the Cossacks. After many difficulties and unavoidable delays, a party composed of Dr. Ebeling, Dr. Oswald and Dr.
Reid continued the search until October 4,
when some Cossacks found Stoeber's body. He
had evidently slipped on a ledge of rocks and
broken his leg. The cold had killed him before
he recovered consciousness. The accident was
entirely due to Stoeber's inexperience in
mountaineering.
Dr. Reid returned by way of Odessa, Constantinople and Athens, and through the Mediterranean to Switzerland. At Crete he saw the
assembled fleet of the powers, and also their
troops, which were stationed at Canea. One
fortress was flying the colors of nearly all the
European nations.
He also ascended Mt.
Stromboli, a well-known volcano in the Lipari
Islands, but was disappointed in not finding
it in activity. In Switzerland he took final
measurements on the Forno glacier.

A series of remarkable lectures on "Modern
Japan" was given during the past week. Dr.
David Murray lectured on "Education in
Japan ;" Professor Mits4kuri gave an account
of "Recent Changes in Japan" and of the "University of Tokio," and Mr. Rokuro Nakaseko,
one of our graduates in chemistry, gave some
charming and realistic glimpses of modern
Japan.
By request of Prof. Brooks, Prof. Mitsukuri spoke before the instructors and students of the Biological Department on Thursday morning, November 18. His interesting
reminiscences and amusing anecdotes of his
student days at the Johns Hopkins afforded a
striking illustration for President Gilman's definition of an university as a"societas magistrorum ct discipulorum." Dr. Sedgwick and Dr.
Wilson were fellow students with Dr. Mitsukuri. Dr. Howell was then an undergraduate
and worked with him in physiology. Professor
Martin and Professor Brooks were the chief instructors of these men. Since then all have
become famous, and have spread abroad the
learning derived from our University. Dr. Mitsukuri took his degree in '83, and is now professor of zoology at the University of Tokio.

Dr. Hollander delivered a lecture upon "The
Present Monetary Condition" on Friday evening before the Historical Seminary. In the
course of his talk he gave a rapid sketch of the
monetary history of the United States, but
dwelt principally upon the modern aspect of the
question, especially as affected by the results of
the Bimetallic Commission. Dr. Hollander, as
Secretary of the Commission, was thrown in
contact with many prominent European statesmen, among whom various opinions on the
matter could be found. The sentiment in favor
of international bimetallism was everywhere
evident, especially in France. The reception in

COLLEGE HALLS.

In this number of the NEWS-LETTER appears
the latter half of a very interesting article by
Professor Herbert B. Adams,on "Student Life
in Edinburgh." In this description of customs
at the University of Edinburgh, Dr. Adams has
brought up a point which merits the thoughtful attention of every member of our University—the existence, namely, of co-operative
college halls.
A distinguished guest of the University—Sir
Michael Foster—has recently said that one
chief source of strength with us lies in the fact
that our University is still young enough to be
moulded—that there are no iron-bound "precedents" to hinder us from developing along
the lines of latest improvement, or from adopting unto ourselves the best features of all other
educational systems.
If we accept this theory of constant improvement by selection as our creed—and we could
not wish for a better one—then it behooves us
to consider carefully this system, only recently
inaugurated at a great sister university, yet already markedly successful there. Until a few
years since, Edinburgh had been, like our-

selves, destitute of any real student life; she
lacked that side of education which does not
come to us from books or lectures, but rather
is absorbed by living in an atmosphere created
by a number of cultivated men and earnest
workers. Now this void has been filled by the
members of the University themselves, and college halls have sprung up and are flourishing
on the co-operative plan, and without any outside backing.
That such a system, if adopted here, would
prove successful, is likely. That it is needed is
unquestionable. Students—especially those
seeking a doctor's degree—are all too prone,
absorbed in their own special line of work, to
forget that duty toward self as an individual, as
well as a unit of social humanity, demands of
them a general and broadening cultivation as
an antidote to the narrowing effect of specializing. Again, who,of all these workers scattered
throughout the city in boarding houses, has not
felt that strain upon the will, greater than any
strain of study, which results from sticking to
work, day by day, monotonously, with hardly
a taste of outside life to relieve the tension?
And,suffering this strain of lonely self-dependence, would he not draw fresh vigor and enthusiasm from an atmosphere of work and
earnest purpose, and from the society of cultivated men, come together in the common
room of the hall for a little rest and chatting
after breakfast or at the end of the day's work?
Such a stimulus is dwelt upon in all stories
and descriptions of English university life,
where this system of halls is in use ; and
it is of only less value than that broadening of character and rubbing away of
angles which results from the contact of
man with his fellow-men. And then there
is the other side, more interesting to undergraduates, perhaps, than to graduates, yet of
importance to both — the fellowship among
students which this system would foster and
the friendships, to whose formation it would
stand sponsor. All these features—quite as
important in their results as the college work—
belong to some extent to the fraternities. But
their scope is limited. The four hundred and

0E44

THE NEWS-LETTER.

I

1

odd members of the University whose homes
are out of the city prove the need, while they
argue the practicability of such a system.
Last year, at the outset of its career, the
NEWS-LETTER outlined two wants as being
most pressing at the University, and pledged
its aid in supplying them. They were, better
athletic facilities, and more college life. Since
then the first of these wants has been filled.
With gratification we realize that a new spirit
has pervaded the whole University from Dan
to Beersheba, from students even unto trustees, and that it has shown itself in the erection
of a cage and the search for a field for our athletes. The second want was for a more mature and definite form of college life. And
this, too, bids fair to be realized. It is shown
in the sentiment against the silly forms of hazing formerly practiced here, as well as in the
establishment of a college congress. And
now, may we not hope that in some future time,
whether near or dim, these halls, which will do
the most of all toward furthering true academic
life, may be embodied in our University? It
is, at least, a pleasant dream to construct them
in fancy. There might be one for medical students, lying conveniently half way between the
Hospital buildings on Broadway, and the Laboratories clustered around McCoy Hall ; another for the graduates and members of the
faculty, a third for undergraduates—all threads
of a web which would bring together the scattered lives of our students--which would bring
about what Dr. Adams calls "the real unity of
academic life—a college centre where students
live and educate one another in their own society—perhaps the most effective of all academic means of culture." Of course, these
halls will not spring into existence spontaneously. But it is possible here, as was the
case in Edinburgh, for a dozen or so students
to club together and
make a beginning. And
from this beginning the development of the
system should be but a question of time.
FOOTBALL.

.t
d

With the St. John's game our football season
Practically closed, as the game with the Baltimore Medical College was regarded as of little

9

importance by Hopkins men, and was played
with enough substitutes to cost us the game.
The victory over our old rivals on Thanksgiving, however, left a very sweet taste in our
mouths, and considerable credit is due the team
for the hard practice and plucky playing which
gave us the victory.
There are, however, one or two lessons to be
learned from the past season which are worth
pointing out. One is, that it is as impossible
as it is unfair to expect the athletic reputation
of a university with nearly six hundred students to be adequately sustained by the almost
unsupported exertions of an undergraduate
body amounting to scarcely one-fourth of the
whole. There is enough good material in the
graduate and medical departments to furnish
the 'Varsity with teams which would place her
on the level where she rightly belongs; but this
material seems quite impossible to be reached.
Occasionally a "grad." tries for the team, and
almost invariably makes it if he practices. But
even this is but the exception which proves
the rule.
The other point is the impossibility of getting the best results out of what material we
have, without adequate grounds and regular
coaching. This was emphasized by the improvement in the team after Mr. Bond took it
in hand. On the whole, however, the result
has been encouraging, and with a cage and an
athletic field we may indulge in a good many
"hopes" for better results next year.

The 'Varsity lost to Gallaudet by 6 to 4, on
Saturday, November 13, in Washington. Gallaudet put up a strong game, and Hopkins
fought fiercely to score, and deserves much
Praise for practically tieing the deaf mutes.
In the first half the 'Varsity eleven went
through Gallaudet's line almost at will, bu,
they were not able to do so in the second. Gallaudet would probably have made ,a better
showing had not their ambition led them to
start before the baIl was in play. They lost a
number of times on this account. The whole
Hopkins eleven did good work. The regrettable feature was that Armstrong had a stiff
breeze in which to try for goal, while the home
players had a perfect calm. Straus scored the
touchdown for Hopkins in the first half.

HOPKINS, 4; B. M. C., 4.
This game between Hopkins and the Baltimore Medical College was not of very great
Interest. The College team outclassed our men
entirely in weight. The 'Varsity team put up
a good showing in
the first half, scoring one
touchdown. In the second half the weight of
the College told upon
our men, and a touchdown was made by the College. The game
ended in a dispute. When the kick for goal
was being tried, the captain ran up and
handled

the ball, putting it in play. Our men naturally
took advantage of this, and carried the ball to
the centre of the field. The College team did
not look upon this in the same light as the
'Varsity did, and refused to play. The referee
decided Hopkins' view correct, and Walter
Camp wrote to Captain Robinson that the decision of the referee is final.
HOCKEY.

The prospects for a good hockey team this
year are unusually bright. This is proven not
only by the large number of candidates, but
also by their enthusiasm and determination.
This season will witness a notable change in
the choosing of the team, as well as of methods
and style in play. The chief feature of the new
arrangement will be the presence of two teams,
one following Hopkins' attack method and the
other the various styles of plays pursued by
other teams. In this manner weak points can
be strengthened and faults remedied.
No man on the team can feel secure of his
place, for a substitute may at any time replace
a regular if by his playing the "sub" proves his
capability of strengthening that position. This
will do away with the discouragement and loss
of interest that usually follows when a man fails
to make a team. The following candidates
have given their names to the manager:
Graduates, S. A. Mitchell, McInnis; M. S.,
W. H. Maddren, G. W. Warren, W. W. Williams, L. V. Hamman, J. M. Hitzrot; Undergraduates, T. Fitzgerald, Jr., W. Straus, C.
Hodges, H. Wright, G. Knapp, J. Levering,

Marshall, A. Wright, 0. Gminder, B. Bernheim, C. Guggenheimer, R. T. Abercrombie,

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE UEOLOGICAL SURVEY.

The State Geological Survey Commission,
composed of Governor Lloyd Lowndes,
Comptroller R. P. Graham, President D. C.
Gilman, and President R. W. Silvester, met at
the Geological Survey headquarters at the
Johns Hopkins University on Tuesday at 3:30
P. M. to listen to the semi- annual report of
Professor William Bullock 'Clark, the State
Geologist. Professor Clark informed the board
of the publication of the first volume of the
'State survey reports, and read extracts from
various letters which had been received from
various sources at home and abroad congratulating the survey and the State upon the high
character of its first publication.
An extended report was given of the present
status of the work and what had been accomplished during the past field season. Professor
Clark stated that between 200 and 300 square
miles in Western Maryland, chiefly in Allegany
county, had been topographically surveyed in
co-operation with the United States Geological Survey ; that the magnetic work had been
further extended, several additional county
towns asking for the co-operation of the State
survey in establishing meridian lines, while all
the magnetic and astronomical work for the
Western Boundary Survey had also been
placed under the supervision of the State Geologist ; that the work inaugurated the previous
year upon the building stones of the State had
been practically brought to a conclusion, and
the preparation of the manuscript of the report
was already well advanced; that detailed geological surveys had been made of Allegany
and Garrett counties and portions of Cecil,
Kent and Anne Arundel counties ; that the
study of the agricultural soils in their relations
to geology had been carried on in the same
counties, and finally that much preliminary
work along various lines of investigation had
been taken up in various portions of the State.
Professor Clark also informed the board regarding his recent attendance upon the International Geological 'Congress at St. Petersburg, where he had been sent by appointment

L-

of the Governor to represent the State as State
Geologist.
After the discussion of plans for future work,
the members of the Commission examined the
large collections which have been brought together under the auspices of the Survey.

STUDENT LIFE IN EDINBURGH.

10

s,

3t.

Life in a Scotch college is well and economically ordered upon the basis of student selfgovernment. There is no needless interference
on the part of the authorities. There is no
watching or supervising, no gating," or shutting in of students at an early evening hour, as
in an English college. In Edinburgh a
student-lodger, as in America, has his own
pass-key and comes or goes when he likes. A
College Hall in Scotland is managed very
much like an American City Club or College
Fraternity House. The Hall chooses its own
officers. A house committee has general
charge of all matters of interior concern. Only
those students are received as members who
are approved or elected. Any obnoxious member may be disciplined or expelled.
The
Charges made for rooms, which are furnished
with all things needful, are according to location. The cost of board is assessed pro rata
upon the members of the common mess, exactly as in old-fashioned student commons, or
dining clubs, at Harvard and Yale.
In the Scotch, as well as in the English colleges, a visitor is impressed with the good administration and efficient household service.
There is a well-developed spirit of social unity
and good fellowship. In these points our
American dormitory system at boys' schools
and men's colleges is, in most cases, weak. The
service and management are usually bad. Our
American colleges for women are far superior
to the old-fashioned dormitories for men. At
Smith and Bryn Mawr, as in English and
Scotch colleges, you will find common diningrooms and common parlors in the buildings
where students lodge. This, of course, promotes sociability, and the common life, which,
in men's colleges, is too often relegated to the

No. 4

fraternity house, the gymnasium, the "cage,"
or the ball field. To this general rule there are
wholesome exceptions a t Lawrenceville,
Worcester Free Academy, Rutger's College,
Trinity College, N. C., and other places.
• The experience of Oxford, Cambridge and
Edinburgh Universities has shown the possibility of good social organization in dormitories and of a real common life in large academic towns, where the individual, unless living in some college, is in danger of isolation
and a more or less hermit mode of existence.
Especially in Edinburgh has the institution of
University Halls, on Castle Hill, socialized and
unified the hitherto separate and scattered elements of the great student body. It is both
feasible and desirable in American college
towns to bring together, in the form of Students' Unions, little bands of congenial spirits,
who can form social clubs, or open fraternities,
to which desirable members may be gradually
elected, upon a broad and liberal plan. The
upper rooms of the club-house, as in our present fraternity houses, should be rented to members. There should be a common room, or
parlor, and a dining-room on the first floor, a
club cuisine in the basement, and bathrooms in
all the upper stories. A club mess can easily be
sustained by residents and boarders under the
direction of a student manager or steward,
who should cater for the club mess and regulate expenses according to the wishes of its patrons. The business affairs of the club, the
election of new members, the collection of
rents, dues, etc., should be in charge of a house
committee. This kind of administration is well
understood in some of our American College
Fraternities, but it needs social extension and
academic popularization.
In the Scotch College Hall at Ramsay Garden I was greatly impressed with the interior
art decorations. As you ascend the winding
stairways, you find the walls beautifully

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

adorned with hundreds of photographs of Old
Edinburgh buildings. Modern improvements
in the "Old Town" on the hill have caused
the removal of many ancient landmarks and
historic monuments, architectural facades and
picturesque courts, or ancient "wyndes,"
which were once the artist's and tourist's delight. You will now find them all preserved in
artistic ways, by drawings and photographs on
the staircases of the College Hall at Ramsay
Garden. In the common room of this hall the
walls are artistically frescoed to represent certain scenes in Celtic mythology. There is an
earnest attempt every year at the Edinburgh
Summer School to revive old Celtic decorative
art, of which a pleasing exhibition is made on
academic premises and in prints and publications.
Edinburgh is a wonderfully beautiful town,
a queenly city, a modern Athens, set upon hills,
with broad thoroughfares, noble monuments
and public buildings, lovely gardens, extensive
parks and drives, magnificent outlooks towards
the mountains and across the Firth of Forth.
But some idea of what the condition of the
town once was can be obtained by glancing at
the squalid "survivals" of filth and misery
in "Cowgate" and other old-time streets and
alleys in which now dwell "the submerged
tenth," apparently sunken below the present
level of the city, whose traffic and modern
promenades are more conspicuously seen
along those gigantic causeways which cross the
old historic ravines or gullies of Edinburgh.
In the newest art gallery of the city you will
find in an upper room a large collection of
sketches and water colors, showing Old Edinburgh in all its picturesque squalor. Almost
every bit of quaint architecture, every nook and
corner of the ancient town, is thus immortalized by the faithful hand of art ; but we must
remember that those old rookeries on High
street and Canongate, while interesting to look
at, were not sanitary places of abode. As Robert Louis Stevenson says : "It is easy to be a
conservator of the discomforts of others. . . .
Assuredly, in driving streets through the black
labyrinth, a few curious old corners have been
swept away, and some associations turned out

of house and home. But what slices of sunlight, what breaths of clean of air, have been
let in I And what a picturesque world remains
untouched I"
Whoever visits Edinburgh will be grateful
to the memory of Robert Louis Stevenson, and
will read and re-read his "Picturesque Notes"
on this fascinating old city. No writer has better caught the spirit of the place or sketched its
salient features with a truer hand. The visitor
will surely encounter this genius loci, Robert
Louis Stevenson, in the National Portrait Gallery of Edinburgh, where a marble bust of the
charming author of "St. Ives" greets you
with an almost life-like welcome. The man
truly lives in literature and in art. The following brief extracts from his "Picturesque Notes"
describe Edinburgh :
"Few places, if any," he says, "offer a more
barbaric display of contrasts to the eye. In the
very midst stands one of the most satisfactory
crags in nature—a bass rock upon dry land,
rooted in a garden, shaken by passing trains,
carrying a crown of battlements and turrets,
and describing its warlike shadow over the
liveliest and brightest thoroughfare of the New
Town. From their smoky beehives, ten stories
high, the unwashed look down upon the open
squares and gardens of the wealthy ; and gay
people sunning themselves along Princes
street, with its mile of commercial palaces beflagged upon some great occasion, see, across a
gardened valley set with statues, where the
washings of the old town flutter in the breeze
at its high windows. And then, upon all sides,
what a clashing of architecture I In this one
valley, where the life of the town goes most
busily forward, there may be seen, shown one
above and behind another by the accidents of
the ground, buildings in almost every style
upon the globe. Egyptian and Greek temples,
Venetian palaces and Gothic spires, are huddled one over another in a most admired disorder; while, above all, the brute mass of the
Castle and the summit of Arthur's Seat look
down upon these imitations with a becoming
dignity, as the works of Nature may look down
upon the monuments of Art."
HERBERT B. ADAMS.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. T11-1011AS.

Dr. James Carey Thomas was born in Baltimore on July II, 1833, and died on November
9, 1897. He graduated from Haverford College in 1852, and from the Medical School of
the University of Maryland in 1854. He was
a trustee of the Johns Hopkins University from
its opening until his death.
His efficient, faithful and devoted work in
many lines is known to all men. He was a
physician in the active practice of that arduous
profession, a minister of the 'Gospel in the Society of Friends, a public-spirited philanthropist, keenly interested in every plan for the improvement of his fellowman ; an officer and a
zealous supporter of the Young Men's Christian Association in this city, and a trustee of
several important educational institutions.
This is not the place to write of these manifold
fields of activity. But it is eminently fitting that
reference should be made in THE NEWS-LETTER to another side of Dr. Thomas' activity to
which he gave much time, thought and love—
his relations to the Johns Hopkins University.
Only the trustees can tell how valuable his
services were in the organization and development of the University in general, and of the
Medical School in particular; but certain of
Dr. Thomas' services were such as could be
seen even by those who came here as students,
and still more clearly by those who remained
as instructors, after the conclusion of their
course of studies for a degree.
First of all, he stood for a broad and courageous Christianity in the University. Other
men might doubt as to the position of Christianity in the mind of an educated man or in the
life of an educational institution ; but we felt
that in him we knew one who never hesitated
in his firm insistence on the greatest freedom
of scientific research and on the certainty and
importance of the Christian religion. None
Should be ignorantly religious; none should
be learned infidels —all should be educated
Christians. With such convictions, he was a
most eager and consistent supporter of everything which tended to make the religious life
more vital to the students.

3

Another service, rendered by Dr. Thomas to
the University, came from his broad culture.
He was the member of the Board of Trustees
with whom (next to President Gilman) the students most frequently came in contact, and in
him we found the true University spirit. He
had none of that narrow specialization into
which professional men are so liable to fall ;
none of that distortion of perspective which
makes the science studied by you so important
and those studied by others so insignificant. In
him we knew a man whose outlook was over a
wide field. He was a truly liberal man. Liberality has been defined as "breadth on high levels," and it seems to me that Dr. Thomas' life
fulfilled that definition. Shallowness was as
foreign to him as narrowness. His breadth
was that of the deep and mighty ocean.
Finally, his life was one of great influence on
Hopkins men because of its kindliness, purity
and lovableness. One could not meet him without a friendly word. To chat with him was to
catch an inspiration to effort, which lingered
long after the conversation was finished. He
was so cheerful, so buoyant and hopeful in his
view of life, so filled with brotherly kindness,
and his face was so turned towards those things
that are pure and lovely, that his presence was
a benediction. Good was it for so many of us
that we knew him,and good was it for the University that his influence was so long manifested and so potent here.
BERNARD C. STEINER.

COLLEGE CONGRESS.

The second regular session of the Senate,
held on Wednesday, November 17, was decidedly more interesting and spirited than the
previous meeting. The debaters displayed
greater self-possession, and were, therefore,
more effective. The side which affirmed that
the "silver question" was now a dead issue, represented by Senators Fisher, R. D. Miller and
Fitzgerald, won by an overwhelming majority.
Senators Fisher and Miller were heartily applauded. The open discussion was participated
in by Senators Ballard and Miller. The meeting was honored by the presence of Professor
Adams, who afterwards gave a favorable criticism of the debate. His advice to the speakers
is to write down their address, as an effective
method of impressing it on the memory, but to
use no notes in speaking, as it is most important to be independent in the delivery.
The subject for the next debate is : Shall
the United States intervene in behalf of Cuba?"
Senators Seth, Clark and Pender will take the
affirmative; Senators Ulman, Stearns and
Hammond 'the negative. President Gilman
will probably be present as the guest of the
Senate.
The third regular meeting of the House of
Representatives was held Wednesday, October
10, in the Donovan room, McCoy ,Hall. Dr.
Adams was the guest of the House. The subject debated was: "Resolved, That the result
of the work of the United States Bimetallic
Monetary 'Commission ought definitely to settle the silver question." The affirmative side
was taken by Congressmen Greenbaum, Fosnocht and Frank; the negative side by Congressmen Gaddess, Levering and Kalb. The
question was very ably debated, and the arguments were effective, especially those of Fosnocht, Levering and Frank. The House took
a very active part in the open discussion. Dr.
Adams, at the request of the House, spoke a
few words. He complimented both the debaters and the House on their able discussion of
the question. The subject for debate at the next

meeting of the House will be : "Resolved, That
the United States should intervene in behalf of
Cuba." The affirmative side will be taken by
Congressmen Chambers, Bruce and Ramsay;
the negative side by Congressmen Fisher, Ross
and Guggenheimer. Dr. Vincent will be the
guest of the House.

ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION.

The newly-organized General Athletic Association is taking active steps to better the
condition of athletics at the University. A field
will be secured and the rent guaranteed for five
years. Five thousand dollars are to be raised,
with the assistance of the alumni, which will be
expended in fitting up the grounds. This will
give our teams next spring good grounds for
out-of-door practice, in addition to the facilities
which the cage will afford, and will also enable
them to make some money on the gate receipts
at games. The graduates and alumni members of the governing board of the Association

THE NEWS-LETTER.
were elected at the last meeting. They are:
Dr. Renouf, Allan McLane, Robert Garrett
and W. H. Maddren. The undergraduate
members of the board will be elected by the
various classes.
THE LITERARY PRIZES.

A few days only remain until December I,
when the time appointed for THE NEWS-LETTER literary contest will close. The Thanksgiving holidays have given some relief from
regular work, and afford an opportunity to
those who have found themselves too busy to
compete. Prof. Adams, Prof. Greene and
Mr. Guy Carleton Lee have consented to act
as judges. The offer is open to students in all
departments of the University. The conditions
are broad, and the prizes are as liberal as we
can make them. The copy of THE NEWSLETTER containing the winning compositions
will go to the exchange table of every prominent college paper in the country. It is important that we be well represented. We look to
the students to make the contest a success.

Prof. Brooks will deliver a series of lectures
on "The Principles of Science as Illustrated by
Zoology," beginning on Monday, November
29,at 5 P. M. These lectures will be held in the
lecture room of the Biological Laboratory, and
are not open to the public.
The Philological Association met Friday,
November 19. Principal paper, "The Sources
of Davenart's Albovine" and "Siege of
Rhodes," Mr. Killis Campbell. Minor communication,"The Arrangement of the Fables
of Marie de France," Mr. Murray Brush.
Dr. F. R. Jones, instructor in political economy has accepted the position of instructor in
history and politics at Union College, Schenectady, N. Y. He left Baltimore last week,
and Dr. Hollander has taken the class in political economy in his stead.

Mayor one of five citizens to act with the law
officers of the city in drafting a new charter for
the city of Baltimore.

University Circular, contains a sketch of Dr.
Humphrey by J. S. Kingsley and B. W. Barton, and a sketch of Dr. Conant by George
Lefevre.
President Gilman has invited Dr. and Mrs.

rIEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

The first Pithotomy of the present academic
year was given on November 27th, at 9 P. M.,
by the fourth year meds., to the rest of that
class and to the faculty and Hospital staff. The
meeting was at the Phi Kappa Psi house. It
included all that was necessary for the comfort
of those present in the line of smoke and drink.
The literary part of the entertainment consisted of stories and songs by various members
of the staff, besides original topical songs by
Mr. Dawson, of the fourth year. The word
"Pithotomy" was coined by the originators of
the society, and is derived from the Greek
word Pithos—"beer jug."
Messrs. Brown and Oliver of the third-year
class have been made demonstrators in anatomy. Messrs. Flint, McCallum and Lewis of
the second-year class have been made assistants in histology. Miss Sabine, also of the second-year class, is now demonstrator in anatomy.
Miss Sabine is about to publish in the Hopkins Hospital reports an article on "The Seventh Cranial."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
DR. REID'S TRIP.

THE LECTURES ON JAPAN.

Dr. H. F. Reid returned from his summer's
trip on Wednesday November 17. He left
Baltimore on June 12, and spent some weeks
taking measurements on the Forno glacier in
the Engadin, together with Professor Ames.
From Switzerland he went to Russia, to take
part in an extensive journey of geologists
across the Ural as far as the Western terminus
of the Great Siberian road. After this he
met Dr. Clark at St. Petersburg, took part in
the Congress, and then joined in a special trip
to Mt. Elbrux in the Caucasus.
In the first days of October an excursion was
made to Mt. Ararat. Mr. E. Stoeber, who ascended the greater Ararat, together with Dr.
Ebeling, of Berlin, and Dr. Oswald, of Bale,
separated from his companions. They gained
the summit, were forced to spend the night at
an altitude of 16,000 feet, suffering much from
cold, and returned to the Cossack camp next
day. There they learned that Stoeber had not
returned. An instant search after the lost man
was rendered fruitless through a violent snowstorm and through the men's inability to speak
Russian with the Cossacks. After many difficulties and unavoidable delays, a party composed of Dr. Ebeling, Dr. Oswald and Dr.
Reid continued the search until October 4,
when some Cossacks found Stoeber's body. He
had evidently slipped on a ledge of rocks and
broken his leg. The cold had killed him before
he recovered consciousness. The accident was
entirely due to Stoeber's inexperience in
mountaineering.
Dr. Reid returned by way of Odessa, Constantinople and Athens, and through the Mediterranean to Switzerland. At Crete he saw the
assembled fleet of the powers, and also their
troops, which were stationed at Canea. One
fortress was flying the colors of nearly all the
European nations.
He also ascended Mt.
Stromboli, a well-known volcano in the Lipari
Islands, but was disappointed in not finding
it in activity. In Switzerland he took final
measurements on the Forno glacier.

A series of remarkable lectures on "Modern
Japan" was given during the past week. Dr.
David Murray lectured on "Education in
Japan ;" Professor Mits4kuri gave an account
of "Recent Changes in Japan" and of the "University of Tokio," and Mr. Rokuro Nakaseko,
one of our graduates in chemistry, gave some
charming and realistic glimpses of modern
Japan.
By request of Prof. Brooks, Prof. Mitsukuri spoke before the instructors and students of the Biological Department on Thursday morning, November 18. His interesting
reminiscences and amusing anecdotes of his
student days at the Johns Hopkins afforded a
striking illustration for President Gilman's definition of an university as a"societas magistrorum ct discipulorum." Dr. Sedgwick and Dr.
Wilson were fellow students with Dr. Mitsukuri. Dr. Howell was then an undergraduate
and worked with him in physiology. Professor
Martin and Professor Brooks were the chief instructors of these men. Since then all have
become famous, and have spread abroad the
learning derived from our University. Dr. Mitsukuri took his degree in '83, and is now professor of zoology at the University of Tokio.

matter could be found. The sentiment in favor
of international bimetallism was everywhere
evident, especially in France. The reception in

COLLEGE HALLS.

In this number of the NEWS-LETTER appears
the latter half of a very interesting article by
Professor Herbert B. Adams,on "Student Life
in Edinburgh." In this description of customs
at the University of Edinburgh, Dr. Adams has
brought up a point which merits the thoughtful attention of every member of our University—the existence, namely, of co-operative
college halls.
A distinguished guest of the University—Sir
Michael Foster—has recently said that one
chief source of strength with us lies in the fact
that our University is still young enough to be
moulded—that there are no iron-bound "precedents" to hinder us from developing along
the lines of latest improvement, or from adopting unto ourselves the best features of all other
educational systems.
If we accept this theory of constant improvement by selection as our creed—and we could
not wish for a better one—then it behooves us
to consider carefully this system, only recently
inaugurated at a great sister university, yet already markedly successful there. Until a few
years since, Edinburgh had been, like our-

selves, destitute of any real student life; she
lacked that side of education which does not
come to us from books or lectures, but rather
is absorbed by living in an atmosphere created
by a number of cultivated men and earnest
workers. Now this void has been filled by the
members of the University themselves, and college halls have sprung up and are flourishing
on the co-operative plan, and without any outside backing.
That such a system, if adopted here, would
prove successful, is likely. That it is needed is
unquestionable. Students—especially those
seeking a doctor's degree—are all too prone,
absorbed in their own special line of work, to
forget that duty toward self as an individual, as
well as a unit of social humanity, demands of
them a general and broadening cultivation as
an antidote to the narrowing effect of specializing. Again, who,of all these workers scattered
throughout the city in boarding houses, has not
felt that strain upon the will, greater than any
strain of study, which results from sticking to
work, day by day, monotonously, with hardly
a taste of outside life to relieve the tension?
And,suffering this strain of lonely self-dependence, would he not draw fresh vigor and enthusiasm from an atmosphere of work and
earnest purpose, and from the society of cultivated men, come together in the common
room of the hall for a little rest and chatting
after breakfast or at the end of the day's work?
Such a stimulus is dwelt upon in all stories
and descriptions of English university life,
where this system of halls is in use ; and
it is of only less value than that broadening of character and rubbing away of
angles which results from the contact of
man with his fellow-men. And then there
is the other side, more interesting to undergraduates, perhaps, than to graduates, yet of
importance to both — the fellowship among
students which this system would foster and
the friendships, to whose formation it would
stand sponsor. All these features—quite as
important in their results as the college work—
belong to some extent to the fraternities. But
their scope is limited. The four hundred and

THE NEWS-LETTER.

I

1

odd members of the University whose homes
are out of the city prove the need, while they
argue the practicability of such a system.
Last year, at the outset of its career, the
NEWS-LETTER outlined two wants as being
most pressing at the University, and pledged
its aid in supplying them. They were, better
athletic facilities, and more college life. Since
then the first of these wants has been filled.
With gratification we realize that a new spirit
has pervaded the whole University from Dan
to Beersheba, from students even unto trustees, and that it has shown itself in the erection
of a cage and the search for a field for our athletes. The second want was for a more mature and definite form of college life. And
this, too, bids fair to be realized. It is shown
in the sentiment against the silly forms of hazing formerly practiced here, as well as in the
establishment of a college congress. And
now, may we not hope that in some future time,
whether near or dim, these halls, which will do
the most of all toward furthering true academic
life, may be embodied in our University? It
is, at least, a pleasant dream to construct them
in fancy. There might be one for medical students, lying conveniently half way between the
Hospital buildings on Broadway, and the Laboratories clustered around McCoy Hall ; another for the graduates and members of the
faculty, a third for undergraduates—all threads
of a web which would bring together the scattered lives of our students--which would bring
about what Dr. Adams calls "the real unity of
academic life—a college centre where students
live and educate one another in their own society—perhaps the most effective of all academic means of culture." Of course, these
halls will not spring into existence spontaneously. But it is possible here, as was the
case in Edinburgh, for a dozen or so students
to club together and
make a beginning. And
from this beginning the development of the
system should be but a question of time.
FOOTBALL.

.t
d

With the St. John's game our football season
Practically closed, as the game with the Baltimore Medical College was regarded as of little

9

importance by Hopkins men, and was played
with enough substitutes to cost us the game.
The victory over our old rivals on Thanksgiving, however, left a very sweet taste in our
mouths, and considerable credit is due the team
for the hard practice and plucky playing which
gave us the victory.
There are, however, one or two lessons to be
learned from the past season which are worth
pointing out. One is, that it is as impossible
as it is unfair to expect the athletic reputation
of a university with nearly six hundred students to be adequately sustained by the almost
unsupported exertions of an undergraduate
body amounting to scarcely one-fourth of the
whole. There is enough good material in the
graduate and medical departments to furnish
the 'Varsity with teams which would place her
on the level where she rightly belongs; but this
material seems quite impossible to be reached.
Occasionally a "grad." tries for the team, and
almost invariably makes it if he practices. But
even this is but the exception which proves
the rule.
The other point is the impossibility of getting the best results out of what material we
have, without adequate grounds and regular
coaching. This was emphasized by the improvement in the team after Mr. Bond took it
in hand. On the whole, however, the result
has been encouraging, and with a cage and an
athletic field we may indulge in a good many
"hopes" for better results next year.

The 'Varsity lost to Gallaudet by 6 to 4, on
Saturday, November 13, in Washington. Gallaudet put up a strong game, and Hopkins
fought fiercely to score, and deserves much
Praise for practically tieing the deaf mutes.
In the first half the 'Varsity eleven went
through Gallaudet's line almost at will, bu,
they were not able to do so in the second. Gallaudet would probably have made ,a better
showing had not their ambition led them to
start before the baIl was in play. They lost a
number of times on this account. The whole
Hopkins eleven did good work. The regrettable feature was that Armstrong had a stiff
breeze in which to try for goal, while the home
players had a perfect calm. Straus scored the
touchdown for Hopkins in the first half.

HOPKINS, 4; B. M. C., 4.
This game between Hopkins and the Baltimore Medical College was not of very great
Interest. The College team outclassed our men
entirely in weight. The 'Varsity team put up
a good showing in
the first half, scoring one
touchdown. In the second half the weight of
the College told upon
our men, and a touchdown was made by the College. The game
ended in a dispute. When the kick for goal
was being tried, the captain ran up and
handled

the ball, putting it in play. Our men naturally
took advantage of this, and carried the ball to
the centre of the field. The College team did
not look upon this in the same light as the
'Varsity did, and refused to play. The referee
decided Hopkins' view correct, and Walter
Camp wrote to Captain Robinson that the decision of the referee is final.
HOCKEY.

The prospects for a good hockey team this
year are unusually bright. This is proven not
only by the large number of candidates, but
also by their enthusiasm and determination.
This season will witness a notable change in
the choosing of the team, as well as of methods
and style in play. The chief feature of the new
arrangement will be the presence of two teams,
one following Hopkins' attack method and the
other the various styles of plays pursued by
other teams. In this manner weak points can
be strengthened and faults remedied.
No man on the team can feel secure of his
place, for a substitute may at any time replace
a regular if by his playing the "sub" proves his
capability of strengthening that position. This
will do away with the discouragement and loss
of interest that usually follows when a man fails
to make a team. The following candidates
have given their names to the manager:
Graduates, S. A. Mitchell, McInnis; M. S.,
W. H. Maddren, G. W. Warren, W. W. Williams, L. V. Hamman, J. M. Hitzrot; Undergraduates, T. Fitzgerald, Jr., W. Straus, C.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE UEOLOGICAL SURVEY.

The State Geological Survey Commission,
composed of Governor Lloyd Lowndes,
Comptroller R. P. Graham, President D. C.
Gilman, and President R. W. Silvester, met at
the Geological Survey headquarters at the
Johns Hopkins University on Tuesday at 3:30
P. M. to listen to the semi- annual report of
Professor William Bullock 'Clark, the State
Geologist. Professor Clark informed the board
of the publication of the first volume of the
'State survey reports, and read extracts from
various letters which had been received from
various sources at home and abroad congratulating the survey and the State upon the high
character of its first publication.
An extended report was given of the present
status of the work and what had been accomplished during the past field season. Professor
Clark stated that between 200 and 300 square
miles in Western Maryland, chiefly in Allegany
county, had been topographically surveyed in
co-operation with the United States Geological Survey ; that the magnetic work had been
further extended, several additional county
towns asking for the co-operation of the State
survey in establishing meridian lines, while all
the magnetic and astronomical work for the
Western Boundary Survey had also been
placed under the supervision of the State Geologist ; that the work inaugurated the previous
year upon the building stones of the State had
been practically brought to a conclusion, and
the preparation of the manuscript of the report
was already well advanced; that detailed geological surveys had been made of Allegany
and Garrett counties and portions of Cecil,
Kent and Anne Arundel counties ; that the
study of the agricultural soils in their relations
to geology had been carried on in the same
counties, and finally that much preliminary
work along various lines of investigation had
been taken up in various portions of the State.
Professor Clark also informed the board regarding his recent attendance upon the International Geological 'Congress at St. Petersburg, where he had been sent by appointment

L-

of the Governor to represent the State as State
Geologist.
After the discussion of plans for future work,
the members of the Commission examined the
large collections which have been brought together under the auspices of the Survey.
